comments.commentBody: How does this differ from the efforts of VW & others to subvert emissions rules? Law-breaking is an option any company can choose if the plan to evade enforcement seems effective, penalties are limited, and individual employees remain unpunished.

"individual employees remain unpunished."

Except that the individual, un-uionized employees "just following orders" _never_ "remain unpunished." It's the executives who "remain unpunished."
Corporations using AI (to identify opponents, including legal officers) to compete with governments, among others. Interesting times that will get yet more interesting.

In Michigan there was one uber driver that went on a mass murder sniper rampage and one that stabbed a customer in the highest end city in the state.  By not following regulations, uber is not a responsible employer, nor service provider.  In addition they pay no taxes for the use of infrastructure they rely on. It is electronic hitch hiking , which illegal almost everywhere.

If you think government regulations would actually serve "as a protection to driver and customers", I've got some real estate in Florida to sell you. These "government regulations" is what created the corrupt and poorly serving taxi industry (in which cities create artificial shortages to boost prices, provide those who support--er donate to--the politicians exclusive medallions). This causes difficulty for riders to find cabs.
Also, the drivers for UberX already pay taxes (including gasoline taxes) to pay for the infrastructure they use, so that's already taken care of.
Lastly, the contractors driving for Uber are given a flexible work option--totally at their choice--to earn money when they otherwise would not. In many foreign countries (like Brazil for instance), it has restored dignity to those who found themselves unemployed for lengthy periods.
Bravo and thank you, Uber!

People love Uber! (As evidenced by their huge ridership.)
It is far more efficient use of resources (thus better for the environment and society in many ways).
It provides those without steady jobs income and dignity, and flexibility.
For its customers, it provides a top level of convenience (the polar opposite of taxis).
To blame Uber for the demise of the taxi industry is like blaming air travel for decline of long haul passenger trains, or synthetic fabrics for the decline of wool recycling.
Bravo and thank you, Uber!

San Francisco streets and those rare free spots in parking lots are now jammed with Ubers looking for a fare. They drive in from Modesto and Sacramento 100 miles away to make a meager living. The bars close at 2 and by 6am there are passengers needing a ride to the airport. After 4 hours sleep in the Safeway parking lot, it's back on the road.
But it's unsustainable not only because the driver eventually has to pay for his car maintenance ond loan. It's unsustainable because there's not enough room on the road for one car to transport each single voyager. NYC subway ridership is down due to Uber. Just imagine one Uber for each strap hanger on just one 8th Ave train. We can't all take Uber. We won't fit on the street, will we!. Mass transit is the only efficient way to move people in city centers.

It's unfortunate that so many people are willing to excuse Uber as long as they can continue to get convenient, cheap rides. We are supposed to be a nation of laws and rules, not a banana republic in which people and companies can arbitrarily decide which rules to follow. The government is trying to conduct an investigation and Uber appears to have taken concrete steps to obfuscate that investigation. We are ok with it as long as the cheap rides continue. What happens when other industries follow this precedent? Would you want your grocery or restaurant or hospital to stamper with investigations? Or will we collectively decide that cheap price is all that matters?
The rules are only in place to perpetuate a corrupt monopolistic model, not to protect anyone.

Cheap prices are very important- they do matter. Government regulations drive up prices and stifle business growth.  Gov''t regulations stifle small business and protect big business from competition. Not good. TRUMP 2016-2024!!!!!!!!

I use Uber a lot because I can no longer drive but am otherwise quite active. At least 50% of the time my driver is , like me, an immigrant,  Cabs are dirty and unreliable. Uber is prompt, clean, polite and affordable since I got rid of my car. They often have very interesting stories. My life, not to mention my marriage, would be miserable without it.

Here's the thing that people don't seem to acknowledge: Uber is only cheap because it doesn't have to abide by costly regulations that traditional can companies do, and they are subsidized by venture capital. They are not yet profitable, but the venture capitalists will not pour money into this forever. The end game is to drive out the traditional taxi companies and then raise prices once they've eliminated the competition. It is a winning strategy for them, if they can survive long enough to implement it. The people who are lauding the cheap prices are in for a ride awakening if Uber survives.

Wal-Mart followed this same strategy and drove out many local competitors. In some cases, after eliminating all options, Wal-Mart stopped serving the area because it wasn't as profitable as it hoped. Now the people in those towns have to drive 20 miles for basics. It is a cautionary tale. Some areas will be left without Uber or any form of taxi service when all is said and done. Enjoy the ride.

So ban Google and Facebook that have replaced news outlets as purveyors of news?  Ban discount airlines like Southwest?  Agreed that these businesses did not exclude customers to outsmart the law.  However your argument is anti-disruption, not pro ethics and legal practice.  Uber practices should be scrutinized in a court of law.

"Boundary pushing workplace culture?"  That's a seriously misleading characterization. They have an incredibly misogynistic and sexist workplace culture where, according to recent articles, sexual harassment has been openly tolerated. That is much more concerning than grey balling.

entrapment is clearly illicit. asking a drug dealer to sell you drugs is entrapment. The legit way is to get the dealer to ask the officer to but drugs. This is very clear precedent. Don't take my word for it, look it up.

In this case the officers were asking drivers to come into an area where they weren't legally allowed to operate , that's entrapment. if they came into the area and offered rides it would be a legit bust.

Another common illicit activity for law enforcement is to arrest people for things that aren't crimes (commonly, but not always, through overcharging like charging a trespassing as a burglary). This is especially troubling because judges and prosecutors AND public defenders have to be in on it. And yet, it's quite common.

Any modern day service company that relies on 'reviews' and the use of people's private auto or home, (AirBnb), is bound to have many problems with many being difficult to resolve.
It's either a totally successful experience or a complete negative one.
Take ALL of those reviews with a grain of salt. Nobody who wants to continue to use the service will ever give a negative review. In fear of receiving one in return. Ever notice all of the roses and sunshine so effervescent in reviews?
The sharing economy is the proverbial box of chocolates-you never know what you're going to get. Stick to reputable businesses who cancel your resos and or refund your money. They also have better insurance and working fire extinguishers/escapes.
Why not allow the users to decide for themselves, rather than taking on the paternalistic tole of protecting them for a hefty fee (taxes) ?

Exactly! Disband the Departments of Defense, the Army, the Air Force, the Marine Corps, and the Coast Guard, saving _trillions_ in taxes. The money can be used by the people to buy assault rifles or whatever else they decide to use for themselves.

This is an utterly biased piece of reporting. The fact is that the luddites (look it up) in the transportation service providers are terrified that they have been simply outsmarted by a tech savvy competitor. When I see the traffic camera at a red light I make sure to stop. This is no different in principle. Do we actually expect people being lured into committing crimes - entrapment- to simply go along for the ride (get it). Portland had no logical reason to ban Uber. Portland could have simply said that the drivers needed to be vetted as taxis are and the the cars needed to meet the same standard at Portland's taxis. Nope. They wanted to maintain the taxi monopolist's profits. Shame on Portland.
Too lazy yourself to?  Figures.

In taxies around the world I have experienced the full gamut of drivers from rude and incompetent to friendly, helpful and capable, so I understand the frustrations of those who welcome Uber’s benefits. But, Uber’s systematic thwarting of the law cannot be excused or ignored without damage to the rule of law. The Portland mayor is right that “the city’s job is to protect the public”; when we operate outside the law we lose the protection of the law. No one should be above the law - not the President, not Uber.

Makes one wonder how many of today's "successful" business models are based solely on finding ways to exploit and violate the law. That would explain a lot of what we see around going on.

I thought I was plenty clever too, when I was a kid, when I learned my dad left his change in his pockets when he hung them on the end of the bed. Why earn and wait for my allowance anymore?
The city government of Portland is all about control, not protection. They hate free enterprise like the Uber business model,where they are not the middlemen.

Um, but the one thing on health care that all Republicans appear to agree on it's taking health care control from the states. They all want "cross-state competition" for health care insurance. But the effect of that (if practical, which is debatable) would be to invalidate state control over their own health insurers, as almost guaranteed you'd end up with all insurers planting themselves (at least nominally) in the state that give them the greatest leeway (as has already happened with credit card companies, all centered in South Dakota - of all places).

"Divide and conquer" Walker's regressive policies in Wisconsin seem to be the blueprint for the Trump administration: Appoint adversaries of agencies to run and disable them; bust unions; undermine ethics enforcement; deny climate change and walk back evironmental protection; demonize Democrats, intimidate protesters, misrepresent tax "reform," let lobbyists write legislation, all the while mouthing pieties about returning control to the people. Walker is an empty suit who owes his prominence to Reince Preibus's political machinations and Koch brothers' money. His tiresome posturing as a heroic figure who refused to be intimidated by protests is belied by the way he knuckles under to big business, big ag and big bucks.
Returning authority to the states is the best solutions to the nation's problems? Not if Wisconsin is your best example. Walker has made a mockery of our state motto, "Forward." This once-progressive state is going backwards in a hurry.

As we will soon find out, it's not the level of government that matters. It's not Federal vs State, it's Republican vs Democrat.

It does not matter if it's at the Federal or State level, if the Republicans are in control then we have the same problems regardless.

"Government is best when close to the governed", yet Walker is best known for turning a deaf ear to the governed in favor of advancing the interests of the Koch brothers.

"Government is best when done on behalf of my campaign donors" would be a much more accurate summation of your ideas, Governor Walker.

In a democracy the refusal of an elected official to adjust or moderate their course of action when faced with overwhelming opposition is a sign of demagoguery or incompetence. Or in the fortunately rare case of the current administration, both.

I find this article puzzling in that it implies more money will be going to schools under the new administration.  We just heard this week that a lot more money will be going to the military budget.  The author does point out something very important: theatrical protests will only get those who dissent so far.  The hard work of true political organization lies ahead if we are to turn the course of this nation toward peace rather than constant war making for profit, health care that enriches people's lives rather than executives and industry that looks to preserve the environment for future generations rather than pillage it for instant gratification.  As taxpayors we need to hold our leaders accountable for using our nation's resources wisely, and transparently.  The voters will need to discriminate closely between rhetoric and reality.

That is not how our representative government is supposed to work.  Elected officials are supposed to represent all constituents, not just the ones who voted for them. And Democrats did vote in the election.

Unclebugs, thanks for your comment. In some ways, Wisconsin is already seeing some of the same issues as Kansas. Our roads are in disrepair. Our teachers have been so badly treated (demonized and lost collective bargaining rights) that we now have a teacher shortage that has led the Dept. of Ed. to look into changing certification so that teachers get a Pre-K through 12 licensure so that we can put teachers in our schools. Our excellent University of Wisconsin system has slipped in national ratings due to cut funding, tuition freezes, and exiting faculty (again, low morale), who take their research funding with them. Programs that study climate change, green farming practices, and protections of our natural resources have seen cuts. Yet, the state gives money to millionaires to build a new basketball arena and votes themselves a 31% per diem increase. Oh, yes, but he's getting people back to work by making them pee in a cup. Our "big and bold" governor, who tells Republicans to "face the voters" and "get to work" doesn't practice what he preaches. His public appearances are by invitation only, and most of his constituents find out he's been in town only after the fact.

There's something to be said for this. The big states will deal with the big problems. The little states will deal with the little problems.

For example, emissions standards for cars could be set in California and the Northeast, where the majority of cars are bought and used. Subsidies for corn and sugar could be borne by the producing states.

There's also the tantalizing possibility of effective gun control. Very tantalizing.

As you read this, remember that democracy has been gerrymandered out of existence in Wisconsin by the Republicans. So they never have to listen to constituents. This makes protest the only way to get them to see opposition.

I'm beginning to be worn down by states' right proponents. Let the states that don't want to fund education, public works, environmental projects, the arts and business incubators have their way.  The Blue states that already fund these things in the Red states (via the federal government) will be more than happy to use these funds for themselves.  Just don't come with "hat in hand" in a few years when things are even worse than they are now.
